abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third, Fourth and Fifth
            Poverty Reduction Support Credits Project for Mali were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was high; Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory; and borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned includes:
            the program was complex, ambitious and clearly did not have
            the full buy-in of the national authorities on key
            structural reforms. The lesson to take from this is that
            credibility of the World Bank is diminished when key actions
            are constantly delayed or watered down to maintain a
            program, such as, for instance, the adoption of a mechanism
            for electricity adjustment. Building a consensus is
            essential for introducing reforms. The decision making
            process is slow in Mali, as leaders seek to build consensus.
            As experience has shown, however, this results in constantly
            postponing much needed reforms. It can also act as a
            smokescreen for a small rent seeking elite that is likely to
            resist any reform that would reduce its privileges, even if
            it would benefit a large part of the population. Technical
            assistance is critical to help a low capacity administration
            implement a complex reform program. Rapid population growth
            (3.6 per cent per annum estimated in the 2009 census) is not
            conducive to significant poverty reduction in a fragile
            environment. Economic growth at about five percent per annum
            is a solid achievement, but not strong enough to make a
            sufficient dent in poverty. The main obstacle to higher
            economic growth is the poor investment climate due to weak
            physical infrastructure, limited access to finance, and
            corruption. Indicators are signals given to stakeholders on
            expected outcomes. They have to be carefully selected and
            monitored. World Bank credibility is diminished when many
            indicators are dropped/revised/introduced in mid-course.
            After an unsatisfactory program, it is necessary to take a
            pause and review in detail with the Government the reasons
            for poor performance. In the health and education sector, a
            lesson from the Poverty Reduction Support Credit (PRSC)
            series is the clear need to continue strengthening service
            delivery for education and health in rural and underserved
            areas for more equitable access. In this perspective, the
            need to move ahead with the decentralization agenda is
            clear, as regards strengthening administrative and
            institutional capacities and financial resources.
